intro: Macrolobium leptorrhachis, commonly known as the slender-stemmed globemallow, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is characterized by its upright, branched stems and showy, yellowish-orange flowers that bloom in late spring. The leaves are alternate, ovate, and have a rough texture, often covered in fine hairs. This species thrives in well-drained soils and full sun, making it adaptable to arid and semi-arid environments. Its botanical features make it a distinctive member of the Malvaceae family, known for its ecological and ornamental value.
